Theſe animals are of the kind with thoſe Lord Mulgrave met with in his voyage to the north pole. Their fleſh is fiſhy; but infinitely ſuperior to the ſea-horſe. But, to return to the Tſchouktſches.

The manners and cuſtoms of this people reſemble much thoſe of the iſlanders of theſe latitudes. Several families often live together in the ſame pit, having their apartments ſeparated by upright poles. The habitation is commonly full of ſmoke; and, is ſo hot, that the women ſit always, ſtark naked, even in the cooleſt part. Every diviſion has its particular lamp of fiſh-oil, and a wick of moſs. Their beds are only low benches, covered with furs; and they are, by conſtitution; ſo inured to the cold, that the flame of a lamp is always ſufficient to warm them in the open air. When they travel, they are drawn in ſledges, by rein-deer. Their canoes are made of the ribs of whales, covered with ſeal-ſkins; and, after the manner of the Greenlanders and Eſquimaux, ſit in them, as in a purſe, drawn cloſe round their body. They are about 12 feet long, narrow, and flat-bottomed.

With reſpect to their ferocity, they are naturally as revengeful and dangerous, as the Tunguſe, their neighbours, are mild and gentle. Twenty Tſchouktſches never heſitate a moment about attacking 50 Koraiks; and, had it not been for the Ruſſian forts, or oſtrogs, the former would long ago have exterminated the whole Koraik nation; nay, the very oſtrogs built in their neighbourhood, are in continual danger.

Notwithſtanding their characteriſtic of ferocity and cruelty, they are very hoſpitable, not compelling their gueſts, indeed, to gorge themſelves, but will kill a rein-deer for their entertainment, which they never do for themſelves. After the manner of the Koraiks, they offer to their gueſts the moſt inchanting beauties at their diſpoſal, to make the night agreeable to them; and theſe fair ones never forget that charming piece of gallantry, of preſenting a cup of their urine to ſuch as accept their favours.

Their manner of taking wives, of educating their children, their rejoicings, and their interments, are exactly the ſame as among the Koriaks. Like them, they are of the Schamane religion. Their ideas of virtue and vice are exceedingly confuſed. It is held criminal to thieve, or murder, in a family, or race, to which a perſon belongs; but theſe crimes, committed elſewhere, are not only allowed, but held honourable and glorious. They have a bad opinion of a young girl,
who has never acquitted herſelf cleverly in ſome theft; and, without ſuch teſtimony of her dexterity and addreſs, ſhe will ſcarcely find a huſband: and robberies committed on the circumjacent families, are conſidered as heroic acts. They ſwear to the truth of a thing in the name of the ſun; and, when conquered by their enemies, give their prieſts as hoſtages, and pledges of their obedience.

They live, in families, according to their races; but have no formal ſuperior. They obey the moſt wealthy and ſagacious among them, preſerving, at the ſame time, the moſt perfect independence, and the right of following each his own particular inclination. They think little of death, bear the troubles inſeparable to human life, with great reluctance; of courſe, are very indifferent as to exiſtence, and ready to terminate their ſufferings by ſuicide; a circumſtance that has thrown great obſtacles in the way of their ſubjection.

div.head: OF THE KURILIANS.
div.p:
THE chain of iſlands running in a ſouth-weſt direction, from the ſouthern promontory of Kamtſchatka to Japan, extending from latitude 51° to 45°, are called
the Kuriles. According to Spanberg, they are 22 in number, not reckoning the ſmall ones. The moſt northern is called Shoomſka, and is not more three leagues from the continent. The next to the ſouth, is called Paramouſir; is much larger than Shoomſka, and inhabited by its own natives; their anceſtors, according to a tradition among them, having come from an iſland rather more to the ſouth, called Onecutan. Thoſe two iſlands were firſt viſited by the Ruſſians, in 1713, and then brought under ſubjection. The others in order are at preſent made tributary; and the paſtor of Paratounca, in Kamtſchatka, is their miſſionary, and viſits them once in three years. The moſt ſouthern iſland, is Nadeegſda, and repreſented by the Ruſſians, who trade to it, as inhabited by a race of men remarkably hairy, and who live in a ſtate of entire independence. Spanberg places this iſland in 43° 50′, N. latitude, and mentions his having watered here; and, that this watering-party brought off eight of the natives, of whom he relates the following circumſtances: That their bodies were covered all over with hair; that ſome of them had ſilver rings, pendant from their ears; that they wore a looſe, ſtriped, ſilk gown, reaching to their ancles; that ſeeing a live cock on deck, they fell on their knees before it; and, likewiſe, before the preſents that were brought to them, cloſing, and ſtretching forth their hands, and bowing their heads, at the ſame time, to the ground; and that, excepting the peculiarity of their hairineſs, they reſembled the other
Kurile iſlanders, and ſpoke the ſame language. The journal of the ſhip Caſhicom, which firſt diſcovered this iſland, and called it Jeſo, ſpeaks of the people being covered with hair. Such a man was, if I recollect right, exhibited ſome time ſince in London; but not from this part of the world.

A trade of barter is carried on between Matmai and the Kurile iſlands, in which, for furs, dried fiſh, and oil, they get ſilk, cotton, iron, and Japaneſe articles of furniture. The inhabitants of as many of the iſlands as are under the dominion of Ruſſia, are converted to chriſtianity; and, probably, the time is not very far diſtant, when a friendly and profitable intercourſe between Kamtſchatka, and this whole chain of iſlands, will be brought about, which will open a communication with Japan itſelf; a very deſireable and advantageous thing to the Ruſſiaas.

Theſe iſlands are all mountainous; and, in ſeveral are volcanoes and hot-ſprings, as in Kamtſchatka. On ſome of them are foreſts, on others, none; but the climate of the whole is temperate. They ſeem to have been formed by a chain of mountains, beginning at Kamtſchatka, and ending at Niphon, whoſe vallies, being ſunk into the ſea, have left their ſummits, above water, of various magnitudes. The neareſt to Kamtſchatka, is Shoomſka, only three leagues from it; and, the furtheſt iſland of the chain, called Matmai, is only
eight leagues from Japan, and about the ſame diſtance from the weſtern continent of China.

The chief of theſe iſlands are inhabited, but many ſmall ones are deſert and uninhabited; and they differ in ſituation, and natural conſtitution; the more northern ones have foreſts of laryx and pines; the more ſouthward, produce canes, bulruſhes, bamboos, vines, &c. In ſome of them are bears, foxes, and jovis muſimon of Pallas. They are not very populous; for, all the iſlands, ſubject to Ruſſia, in 1766, were enrolled at no more than 262 males. They are a friendly, hoſpitable, generous, humane, race of people; excelling the Kamtſchadales, not leſs in the formation of their bodies, than in the docility and quickneſs of their underſtandings. Their language is agreeable to the ear, and they ſpeak and pronounce it ſlowly. Their habitations are dug in the earth, like the Kamtſchadales, only neater; are wainſcoted and furniſhed with Japan goods. Their food conſiſts of amphibious and ſea-animals, and all kinds of game, fowls, fiſh, fruits, wild roots, and ſea-cabbages, a ſpecies of the fuci, and alſo ſweetmeats from Japan.

The dreſs of the northern iſlanders reſembles that of the Tunguſe. It is made of ſwan-ſkin, and other aquatic fowls. They cut their hair cloſe to the head, and wear hats, woven of reeds. The ſouthern Kurilians love a thick beard, let their hair grow, and ſtain their
lips black. Theſe dreſs like the Chineſe, and wear a Japan fabre, ſlung in a girdle over their robe; but wear no breeches. The women dreſs like the men, but ſtain their lips blacker, and mark their faces, hands and arms, with black figures. Fond of foreign faſhions, they adopt them, and mix them with their more natural dreſs. Priding themſelves in a variety of colours, they get their cloaths from Japan; but are very dirty and ſlovenly.

Their manner of taking a wife, is much like that of the Kamtſchadales. The lover does all he can to obtain the laſt favour; this done, he carries her off. If ſhe proves unfaithful, the huſband challenges the gallant; and, in their duels, each ſtrikes his antagoniſt three blows, by turns. The women have difficult labours; the midwife names the child, without ceremony. The ſouthern iſlands bury their dead; but the northern ones, cover ſuch as die, in the winter, with ſtraw, and leave them. They have a particular veneration for old men; and, when any iſlanders make a viſit to ſome neighbouring iſle, the inhabitants take up their arms, and dreſs to receive them. They treat them like friends; ſalute them, by bending the knee, embrace, and kiſs. Some of them have ſo much ſenſibility, at theſe friendly interviews, as to ſhed tears. After the firſt ſalutations, the oldeſt in company makes a ſpeech, in which he relates his adventures, and what has happened to him, and his friend, ſince the laſt viſit;
all the company ſtanding up, during the recital, and liſtening with the profoundeſt attention. This orator having finiſhed, he to whom the viſit is paid, makes a ſpeech in his turn, and every one declares he is much intereſted in all that hath happened to the reſt. After theſe aſſurances of reciprocal friendſhip, an entertainment takes place, but filthy enough; they ſing, dance, and tell tales. Their expreſſions are tender, modeſt, and becoming; and, as they hate lies and fraud, they always ſpeak the truth, with the utmoſt fidelity.

div.head: OF THE EASTERN ISLANDS.
div.p: AMERICA, we have obſerved, is ſeparated from the eaſtern coaſt of Siberia, and continent of Aſia, by a ſtreight; in which are many iſlands, of various magnitude; theſe alſo are under the dominion of Ruſſia. Some of thoſe neareſt to the coaſt of Siberia, have been ſubject to Ruſſia ever ſince they have been in poſſeſſion of Siberia. Some of the larger, and at a greater diſtance from the continent, have been but lately viſited by the Ruſſians; and many, doubtleſs, are undiſcovered. Captain King, who went out with Captain Cooke, in his laſt voyage, touched at one of them; and, from him, and ſome of the Ruſſian navigators, we ſhall be able to give the reader a tolerable account of them.

figure.head: A Map Comprehending BHERINGS STRAITS, with the adjoining Coaſts of ASIA & AMERICA.

div.p: Theſe iſlands are ſuppoſed to extend from the peninſula of Kamtſchatka, to the continent of America, in the direction weſt ſouth-weſt, to eaſt north-eaſt, from about 56 degrees north latitude to 61; one of the largeſt of theſe iſlands, is Koumandirſkoi, lying about 63 leagues eaſt of the mouth of the river Kamtſchatka; and is about 60 miles in length. The land Oumnakis about 63 leagues in circuit, and Ounalaſhka, is larger than this.

Some of theſe iſlands are ſo near the coaſt of Siberia, that the Tſchouktſches venture over in their little canoes; and the neareſt, to the American coaſt, is ſuppoſed to be the iſland of Kadyak. All theſe iſlands are alike, with reſpect to ſoil: they are ſtony, mountainous, boggy, wild, and uncultivated. In their produce they differ, according to their ſituation and climate. Some are covered with foreſts, and abound with foreſt-game. The more ſouthern are bare of wood; but abound in foxes, and other animals, that love an open country. The ſea-otter, Muſtela Lutris, ſea-lion, Phoca Leonina, ſea-bear, Phoca Urſina, ſeals, and other amphibious animals, are found on their ſhores; and the ſea throws up ſea-cabbages, muſcles, a variety of ſhell-fiſh, and a quantity of floating timber.

Some of theſe iſlands are inhabited, others not; and thoſe which are, but thinly; ſome having but two or three families, and ſome not exceeding 100. The
Ruſſians have no ſettlement on any of them; but, in 1766, enrolled the inhabitants of all they viſited, and could make no more than 367 tributary-males in the whole.

Two Ruſſian veſſels make the voyage of ſome of theſe iſlands once a year, and collect a tribute from all they viſit. The different iſlanders ſeem to be about as much diſtinguiſhable from each other, as the different Tartar tribes in Siberia; and their language varys but little. The natives of Kadiak, call themſelves Kanaguil, not unlike Karalit, the name of the Greenlanders, and the Eſquimaux Indians.

Of Ounalaſkka, we ſhall ſpeak more particularly.— The inhabitants of theſe iſlands, in general, are ſtout and robuſt, but active. Their faces are flat, and their ſkins fair. They have lank, black hair, and but little beard. They have a good ſhare of plain, natural underſtanding; and their children learn foreign languages with great facility. They ſeem cold and indifferent in all their actions; but, rouſe them, and they are furious and revengful, without any regard to conſequences. The leaſt apprehenſion, drives them to deſpair; and, the leaſt affliction, to ſelf-murder. Though free and independent, they are neither fraudulent nor perfidious. They will offer their wives to thoſe who behave friendly to them; but, whoever ſhall preſume to offer violence to a woman, is ſure to pay the forfeit of his life.

There is ſuch a perfect equality among them, that they have no chief, or ſuperior, nor any law, or puniſhment. They enjoy life, without any bitter recollection of the paſt, or any anxious ſolicitude for the future. They live in a ſociety of families, called a race, mutually defending each other. If ſtrangers, of a neighbouring iſle, come to viſit them in ſmall companies, they are amicably received; but, if in larger bands, they are repulſed with arms, the inhabitants of the ſame iſland conſidering that iſland as their own. They have no knowledge of letters, are ignorant of their own hiſtory, totally void of education, or any kind of information, but what immediately reſpects their way of life. To give a ſpecimen of their language: Agaïya, ſignifies the ſun; Touguilag, the moon; Tana, the water; Katſchik, the wind; Kiguenag, fire; Taïyagha, man; Ayagout, woman; Yaga, wood.

They have no connexion with any iſland but their own; and have no domeſtic animals, not even dogs. Game they kill with ſnares and arrows, and fiſh, by incloſing parts of rivers, and catching it in baſkets. The women are employed in this buſineſs, equally with the men, and partake of all their labours. The Siberian women ſurpaſs theſe in tanning; but theſe ſurpaſs the Siberians in embroidery. They dreſs in furs; and ſince the arrival of the Ruſſians among them, wear the worſt, and barter away the beſt, for ſhreds and remnants of cloth, thread, needles, beads, and other trifles.

Theſe happy people are ſo contented with their lot, that the maſter of a tolerably good pit, thinks himſelf the firſt man in the world, provided he has a good number of women, a ſtrong canoe, and ſuch cloaths as would be conſidered as handſome in no other place. Yet theſe haughty iſlanders do not poſſeſs the leaſt article, that would have any value with an European; nay, they ſcarce enjoy ſo much authority, as to make their children, in the leaſt, obedient.

Their arms and moveables are a perfect picture of the infancy of the world. The bow and arrow, the dart, the lance, and the ſling, the club, and the ſhield, are all their weapons; and they can throw a javelin, three feet long, to the diſtance of 30 fathoms, equal to a Greenlander.

Their baidars, or boats, are ſeveral fathoms long, and will carry from five to 40 perſons. They are badly made, and with much trouble, being conſtructed of floating timber, hewn with ſharp ſtones, or of the ribs of a whale, covered with ſea-horſe ſkin. Their common canoes hold no more than two perſons, and ſeldom weigh more than about 25lb.

Their habitations are like the Kamtſchadales, only larger. Their beds are mats, or furs; and they light their pits with lamps, ſuſpended from the roof. A whole village, or ſeveral families, will live in a ſingle pit, to
the number of from 50 to 300 perſons; and a ſtranger, firſt entering them, by a hole in the roof, muſt conceive he is deſcending into hell. A gloomy darkneſs, a thick ſmoke, a heat, often inſupportable; the pale light of ſtinking tapers, a number of beings, all wild and naked, having nothing human but the figure; a great abundance of vermin; food, the moſt miſerable and diſguſtful, a conſtant noiſe and din, a horrible ſtench, worſe than that of Styx. All theſe together form the picture preſented to a ſtranger deſcending into theſe ſubterranean caverns: but they have ſummer-huts alſo, like the Kamtſchatdales, abounding alſo with inhabitants. Many of them paſs their whole life in holes of rocks, or in natural caverns which they find.

Their furniture is as ſimple as their houſes; troughs, made of drift wood, ſhells, hollowed ſtones, baſkets, bark and leather-veſſels, ſtraw mats, ſharp ſtone-hatchets and knives, utenſils of bone; and, where the Ruſſians uſually land, ſome few ſkillets and boilers.

Perſuaded that Nature never meant to conceal • heir ſhape, they go always naked within their huts, as well adults as children. Indeed their huts are kept ſo hot, that dreſs would be burthenſome. In this eaſy negligence the two ſexes converſe together; and whenever they are abroad, they throw of all their dreſs as ſoon as it becomes inconvenient. Some, however, wear a
fur, or leather-apron; and many, like our forefathers, hide their nakedneſs only with a leaf; not ſo much for decency, as ſecurity againſt injury.

In many of the iſles, both ſexes ornament their faces, arms and hands, by ſtaining them, with the figures of birds, beaſts and flowers; by pricking the ſkin till it bleeds, and rubbing the part with a black powder. Many bore their ears with a number of holes, through which paſs gaudy feathers, ſtrings of beads, and other ornaments. As a great quantity of hair is by them eſteemed ugly, the men pluck out the greateſt part of their beards by the roots; the women cut their hair before, and tie up the reſt, on the crown, in a treſs. Some men ſhave their heads cloſe, with ſharp ſtones, and others leave a round tonſure. The generality are ſo filthy, as never to waſh themſelves; and, with their naſtineſs, and copper complexion, are truly ugly. Thoſe who do waſh, waſh with their own water, and then with ſpring-water; and theſe have a good ſkin, and look freſh and well. Both men and women, throughout the iſles, make two deep inciſions, when young, in the lower lip, and a hole in the cartilaginous ſeparation of the noſtrils; and, when they mean to dreſs, fix, in theſe inciſions in the lip, two ſlender teeth, turned upwards, and ſmoothly poliſhed, about two inches long; through the hole in their noſe, they paſs a little bone of a bird, in order to ſwell out the noſtrils. Some, that wiſh to be ſmarter than ordinary,
will make a third inciſion in the lip, and fix ſome coloured ſtone in it.

When they wear a dreſs, it is a frock, like that of the Koraiks, reaching to the knees, made of the belly-ſkin of various water-fowl. Thoſe of the women are made of ſkins, with the fur inwards, and worn next the ſkin, the outſide ſtained with a red earth; and this is all their dreſs, except, in ſummer, they will ſometimes wear a wooden hat, ſcooped out in the ſhape of a duck's beak, about 18 inches long, from the fore part to the hind; theſe they paint with coloured earths, decorate the edges with feathers, the crown with a bunch of ſea-lion's hair, eight or ten inches long, and ſurround them with glaſs, lead, and bunches of feathers, ſo as to reſemble a Roman helmet. Some on the top place an image of a man ſitting, about an inch high, tolerably well covered in ſtone. Other iſlanders wear conical caps, made of ſkin, and embroidered, with broad fringes of hair, and the ſides and borders ornamented with feathers, and embroidered with the ſinews of animals, hair, and glaſs beads, which they get from the Ruſſians. Others will ſkin a water-fowl, in ſuch a manner, that the neck, wings and tail, ſhall remain with the ſkin; and, in drying them, keep the head and neck erect, and the whole in a good ſhape, and put their head into the body of the bird: theſe caps are worn by women, and are the handſomeſt part of their dreſs. They vary theſe caps in a number of ways, but all equally ornamented.
Their beſt garments are made of the belly-ſkins of different fowls, ſhaped like ſhifts, and reaching to their heels; the borders prettily embroidered, two inches broad; and, a quantity of ſtripes of fine furs, ſix or eight inches long, tied all round it; at bottom, there is a furbelow, ſix inches broad, made of a number of ſtrait ſlips of ſkin.

Their food is agreeable to what the iſlands produce. They eat whales, ſea-horſes, porpoiſes, ſea-otters, ſea-bears, ſea-lions, beaſts of prey, and other game; all ſorts of fowl, birds of prey, and others, and all kind of fiſh; in ſhort, except inſects, and their fellow-creatures, nothing comes amiſs to them, either in the animal or vegetable kingdom; and they will eat them half-rotten. Salt is unknown to them. Generally ſpeaking, they eat all their food raw; ſo that, the blood of the fleſh they devour, runs out of their mouths, through the inciſions in the lower lip. What they do dreſs, is either warmed in the flame of their ſtinking lamps, by ſticking it on large ſkewers, and turning it round in that flame; or, by ſtewing it between two ſtones, hollowed out for a pan and its cover; the joints being cemented with clay; after thus dreſſing it, they ſet it by till it is cold. Their drink is water; and, if they have not freſh at hand, they will drink ſea-water. As a treat, they will gulp down the blubber of whales, porpoiſes, or other fiſh. They are not fond of ſpirituous liquors; but, from the Ruſſians, many of them have learnt to take ſnuff.

Every family or village has a certain extent of ſea-coaſt appropriated to their ſole uſe, from which they collect for food any fiſh, or dead animals that may be caſt aſhore; nor does any ſtranger preſume to invade this territory; if he does, he is in danger of being ſhot, or knocked on the head.

Simple and natural as the life of theſe iſlanders is, it does no great credit to the ſtate of nature, as the natives are but a ſmall degree above the level of the brute creation. They are of a ſerious turn, very laconic in their converſation, rude, and uncivilized; but at the ſame time, from careleſſneſs, generous and hoſpitable. They have no id •• of ſubordination or decorum, but every one follows his own propenſities; eating when they are hungry, and even performing the evacuations of nature whilſt they are eating. Children almoſt fill the pit, in which they live with their ordure; and grown perſons ſeldom go further than the roof; of courſe the ſtench is intolerable. In times of ſcarcity they will faſt ſeveral days together. At home they go quite naked, practiſe propagation as their inclination leads them, whether in public or out, without any reſerve; and the women are delivered in the preſence of any one that may chance to be with them, without the leaſt privacy. Their beds are mats, and their cloaths are their only covering.

Their matrimonial connexions ſcarce deſerve the name of marriage. A boy, old enough to hunt or
catch fiſh, takes home one or two girls or women, and they live together in the ſame pit, without any previous contract. A man generally ſelects his firſt wives himſelf; but if he is a ſtout fellow, and a good huntſman or fiſherman, maidens, deſerted women, widows, and wives diſmiſſed from their huſbands, will offer themſelves to them; ſo that many will have four, five, or ſix wives. Where a houſehold has been thus formed, there is generally a gang of old men, women, and children. All are welcome, and employed according to their ſtrength; but when times are not proſperous with ſuch a family, they diſperſe as eaſily as they form. The men go to ſeek proviſions elſewhere; women take to other men, and carry their children with them; and this without diſorder or diſpute; for the women are as independent and free as the men. Men will ſometimes truck away their wives and children; and ſuch wives and children will ſometimes return to their original home: and in this pure ſtate of nature, we ſee fewer diſagreeable conſequences than under more regular inſtitutions.

Ignorant of the excluſive right of a married ſtate, theſe iſlanders know no jealouſy, but leave their wives in a perfect freedom of promiſcuous intercourſe with other men. As they engage in wedlock with no other motive than to have an aſſiſtance in gaining a livelihood, they are not ſubject to exceſſive libertiniſm. They neither envy any man's pleaſure, or good fortune;
and, as buxom women are preferred to maidens, girls are ſuffered to grow up in perfect liberty, totally unconſtrained by either virtue or modeſty.

Women have eaſy labours; frequently bathe their children in cold ſea-water; and, whenever a child cries, it is plunged under water, even in the coldeſt weather, till it is ſilent. They ſuckle their infants but a ſhort time, feeding them with raw and groſs meat; and, to make them ſquat down on their heels, often tie their feet together, and place them in that attitude.

But, ſavage as they are, they are not inſenſible, but will ſeek to ſoften the rubs of life by various amuſements. They make no feſtivals either at their nuptials, the birth of their children, or their religious exerciſes; yet they paſs the whole month of December in viſiting, not only their neighbours, but the adjacent iſles. A ſucceſsful chace, a viſit from an unexpected friend, or the carcaſe of a whale thrown on the coaſt • will cauſe a rejoicing. On this latter occaſion, that of a whale being caſt aſhore, it becomes the property of the whole iſland; the people aſſemble from all parts, expreſs the moſt extravagant joy, perform idolatrous worſhip round the animal; then ſtrip themſelves naked, and proceed to cut up and divide the prey. This done, they put on their beſt cloaths, ſwell out their noſtrils, decorate their lips with crooked bones, and devour all
the parts that are eatable with demonſtrations of exceſſive tranſport. At theſe celebrations they beat a kind of kettle drum, ſing, dance, tell ſtories, and indulge their amorous propenſities. This drum is the only muſical inſtrument they have; and they dance, and beat it in proceſſion before their viſitors. Their dances are regular, but backwards and forwards; ſeveral perſons make a long ſtring, and perform a number of leaps and geſticulations. They have at this time alſo maſquerades, concealing their faces with wooden maſks, repreſenting the form of various animals. The men attend theſe quite naked, except a ſmall apron or purſe worn before; but the women ate cloathed. Having danced enough, they break their drums and maſks; couches are then brought, the women are courted, and the hoſt of the entertainment furniſhes ſuch of his gueſts with ladies as brought none with them. When their viſitors are leaving them, the parting is cold; the hoſt neither conducting them on their way, nor the gueſts expreſſing any thanks for the kind reception they have met with.

They are pagans, and their faith is Schamaniſm, as is indeed that of all the Eaſtern Siberians; though leſs ſenſual than theſe iſlanders. They have no diſtinct idea of gods, their influence on mankind, nor of a future ſtate. They have neither feſtivals, nor any degree of worſhip. Their magic prieſts are like thoſe of Kamtſchatka,, who pretend to be related to, and connected
with ſpirits, and boaſt of knowing the paſt and the future.

Like other Schamanders, they inter with the dead ſundry utenſils, to enable them to begin the other world with. They ſuppoſe the volcanoes, the ſmoking rocks of their iſland, and ſundry great caverns, to be the abode of their ſpirits, and to theſe objects their prayers are addreſſed; but they have in their habitations certain ſmall idols, which they rub with blood and greaſe, as their food. They are terrified at ghoſts and ſpectres; and it is with great reluctance that they inhabit the huts of any deceaſed perſon; of courſe, left ſuch huts ſhould be uſeleſs, they carry the ſick out of them, and ſuffer them to die in the open air. They bury their poor in their cloaths, wrapping them up in mat, with certain utenſils and implements of hunting; but the rich they dreſs in their beſt garments, place them in a little canoe, hang it to a kind of gallows, and thus ſuffer it to rot in the air.

They have generally a good conſtitution, and preſerve it to a very advanced age. The ſmall-pox is unknown to them; and the ſcurvy, itch, fevers, and many other diſtempers, are ſeldom met with. Their teeth continue firm and white even to old age; and if any one finds himſelf unwell, he keeps a perfect regimen for a few days, and is perfectly recovered. For the head-ach they open a vein in the head with a ſharp
flint, and dreſs their wounds with healing herbs, which their country affords. They have little fear of pain; and as they make glue by a preparation of the blood of animals, if they have no ſuch blood at hand, they will, without heſitation, ſtrike themſelves on the noſe with their fiſt, and attain from themſelves as much as they have occaſion for.

The Ruſſian troops and merchants, Coſſacks, and others, who frequent theſe iſlands, lead but a troubleſome life. They embark at Kamtſchatſka, viſit different places, and ſeldom perform the voyage in leſs than a year. At theſe times they receive the tribute, barter with the natives a variety of ſmall merchandize, beads, and trinkets for furs. The Ruſſians themſelves are ſuffered to hunt when there, and the Tartars will attend them on the occaſion. The Ruſſians have their own barracks on ſhore; never lodge with the natives, nor truſt themſelves alone with them; for though the iſlanders generally treat them with curteſy, yet, if any ſuſpicion is broad, they reſolve on deſtroying every foreigner, and that without reflection.

Oonalahſka.—Of all the groupes of iſlands in the north-ſea, that, of which Oonalahſka is one, is by far the greateſt, and this iſland the principal of them all. This group extends 40 leagues from Oonalahſka to F. N. F. The Ruſſians have a ſettlement on this iſland, which at preſent conſiſts only of a dwelling-houſe and two ſtore-houſes. Beſides the Ruſſians reſident here, are a
number of Kamtſchadales; and ſome of the natives, as ſervants, or ſlaves, to the former. Theſe all live in the ſame houſe; the Ruſſians at the upper end, the Kamtſchadales in the middle, and the natives at the lower end; where is fixed a large boiler for preparing their food, which conſiſts chiefly of what the ſea produces, with the addition of wild roots and berries. There are Ruſſians ſettled on all the principal iſlands, between Oonalaſhka and Kamtſchatka, for the ſole purpoſe of collecting furs. Their great object is the ſea-beaver, or otter: they have frequented Oonalaſhka, ſince the year 1762. The latitude of Samganoodka, the principal haven of Oonalaſhka, and where Captain Cooke lay, in October, 1778, is 53° 5 min. N. the longitude, 193° 30 min. W.

The Ruſſians here ſettled, are obliged to put up with the food of the country; but Captain Cooke ſays, he got ſome whale's fleſh of their dreſſing, and it was very palatable; and they treated him with a kind of pan-pudding, made of ſalmon-roe, beat up very fine, and fried, which is a good ſuccedaneum for bread, which they ſeldom can procure. As to liquor they have none, but the juice of berries, which they ſip at meals. As the iſland ſupplies them with food, ſo does it with clothes, which conſiſt chiefly of ſkins. Their upper garment is made like our waggoner's frock, and reaches to their knees. Beſides this, they wear a waiſtcoat, or two, a pair of breeches, a fur cap, and a pair of boots,
the ſoles and upper leathers of which, are made of Ruſſian leather, but the legs of ſtrong gut.

The natives are, to all appearance, peaceable and inoffenſive, and honeſt to the extreme; perhaps, made ſo from ſtrict diſcipline. They have their own chiefs on each iſland, and ſeem to enjoy liberty and property unmoleſted. They are low of ſtature, but plump and well-ſhaped, with ſhort necks, chubby faces, black eyes, ſmall hands, and long, ſtrait, black hair, which the men wear looſe behind, and cut before; but the women tie up in a bunch.

Both ſexes wear the ſame kind of cloaths; the difference is only in the materials. The woman's frock is made of ſeal-ſkin, like a carter's frock; that of the men, is made of the ſkin of birds: both reach below the knee. This is the whole dreſs of the women: but the men wear, over their frock, another, made of gut, which repels water, and has a hood over it, that draws over the head. Some wear boots; and, all of them, a kind of oval-ſnouted cap, made of wood, with a rim, to admit the head. Theſe caps are dyed with green, and other colours; and, round the upper part of the rim, are ſtuck the long briſtles of ſome ſea-animal: on which are ſtrung glaſs beads; and, in the front, is a ſmall image, or two, made of bone.

They uſe no paint; but, the women puncture their faces ſlightly; and, both men and women, bore the under lip, in which they fix pieces of ſtone. At Oonalaſhka, indeed, it is an ornament only uſed by the women. Some fix beads to the upper lip; and, all of them, hang ornaments in their ears.

Their food conſiſts of fiſh, ſea-animals, birds, roots, berries, and ſea-weeds. They dry large quantities of fiſh in ſummer; which they lay up, in ſmall huts, for winter-uſe; and, probably, they preſerve roots and berries for the ſame time of ſcarcity. Every thing is eaten almoſt raw: boiling and roaſting are their only means of cookery. Some have got little braſs kettles; and, thoſe who have not, make one of a flat ſtone, with ſides of clay, not unlike a raiſed pye. I was once preſent, ſays Captain Cooke, when the chief of Oonalaſhka made his dinner of the raw head of a large halibut, juſt caught. Before any was given to the chief, two of his ſervants eat the gills, without any other preparation than ſqueezing out the ſlime. This done, one of them cut off the head of the fiſh, took it to the ſea, and waſhed it, then came with it, and ſat down by the chief; firſt pulling up ſome graſs, upon a part of which the head was laid, and the reſt was ſtrewed before the chief. He then cut large pieces of the cheeks, and laid theſe within the reach of the great man, who ſwallowed them with as much ſatisfaction as we ſhould do raw oyſters. When he had done, the remains of the head were cut
in pieces, and given to the attendants, who tore off the meat with their teeth, and gnawed the bones, like ſo many dogs.

As theſe people uſe no paint, they are not ſo dirty in their perſons as the ſavages that do; but they are equally louſy, and filthy in their houſes. They live in a pit, as do the Kamtſchadales; generally an oblong ſquare, about 50 feet by 20. Over this pit is raiſed a wooden roof, firſt covered with graſs, and then with earth; ſo that, without, it has the appearance of a dunghill. In the middle of this roof, towards each end, is left a ſquare hole; one to admit the light, and the other for an entrance; as, by this hole, they deſcend into the hut by a poſt, with ſteps into it. Round the ſides and ends of the huts, the families (for ſeveral lodge in one houſe) have their ſeparate apartments, where they ſleep, and ſit at work, not on benches, but in a kind of concave trench, dug all round the inſide, and covered with mats; ſo, that this part is kept tolerably decent, but the middle of the hut, common to all, is far otherwiſe. For, although it is covered with dry graſs, it is a receſs liable for all kinds of filth; and the place for the urine-trough, the ſtench of which is not mended, by raw hides, or leather, being conſtantly ſteeped in it. Behind, and over the trench, are placed the few effects they are poſſeſſed of; ſuch as their cloaths, mats, and ſkins.

figure.head: INSIDE OF A HOUSE AT OONALASHKA.

div.p: Their furniture conſiſts of bowls, ſpoons, buckets, cans, matted baſkets, and, perhaps, a Ruſſian kettle, or pot. All theſe utenſils are very neatly made, and well formed; and, yet they have no other tools, than a ſmall piece of iron, fitted into a crooked, wooden handle, reſembling an adze, and a knife. There are few, if any of them, that do not take ſnuff, chew and ſmoke tobacco—a luxury that bids fair to keep them poor.

They did not ſeem, continues Captain Cooke, to covet any other iron inſtruments than needles to ſew their canoes, and make and embroider their clothes. For thread, they uſe the ſinews of animals. They are excellent makers of baſkets and mats, which are not only beautiful, but ſtrong; in ſhort, there is ſuch a neatneſs and perfection in moſt of their workmanſhip, that ſhews, they neither want ingenuity, or perſeverance.

Their houſes are lighted, and heated, by lamps; having no fire-places. Theſe lamps are made of a flat ſtone, hollowed out like a plate, about the ſize of one, filled with oil, and the wick is a piece of dried graſs; over theſe, they occaſionally ſit, and warm themſelves. Fire is produced, both by colliſion and attrition; the former, by ſtriking two ſtones againſt each other, on one of which brimſtone is rubbed; the other, by two
pieces of wood, as among the Kamtſchadales, Greenlanders, and Eſkimaux Indians.

No ſuch thing as a weapon is to be ſeen among them; having, probably, been diſarmed by the Ruſſians: nor have they any large canoes; probably, likewiſe, a political prohibition. Their canoes are built after the manner of the Greenlanders: they are about 12 feet long, a foot and a half broad in the middle, and 12 or 14 inches deep. They will occaſionally carry two perſons, one of whom is ſtretched at full length in the canoe, and the other ſits in the ſeat, or round hole, which is nearly in the middle. Round this hole, is a rim, or hoop of wood, about which is ſewed gut-ſkin, that can be drawn together, or opened, like a purſe. The man ſeats himſelf in this place, draws the ſkin tight round his body, over his gut-frock, and brings the ends of the purſe-ſkin over the ſhoulder, to keep it in its place. The ſleeves of his frock are tied round his wriſt; and, it being cloſe round his neck, and the hood drawn over his head, and theſe confined by his cap, the water can ſcarcely penetrate either to his body, or into the canoe: if it ſhould, it is taken out of the canoe with a ſponge. They will put their canoes on, at the rate of ſeven miles an hour, by ſtriking the water with a quick, regular motion, on each ſide the canoe, with a double-bladed paddle, which they hold, with both hands, in the middle.
Their fiſhing and hunting-implements lie ready on their canoes for uſe, ſtrapped on, for ſafety; and differ little from thoſe uſed by the Greenlanders.

Fiſhes common to other northern ſeas are found here, north of 60°. Small fiſh is not to be met with; but the whales are more numerous. Sea-horſes are ſeen in prodigious numbers about the ice; and the ſea-otter is an animal peculiar to this ſea.

The few land-birds we ſaw, ſays Captain Cooke, are the ſame with thoſe in Europe; but, there are many others, I had not an opportunity of knowing. Sea and water-fowls are not met with here in ſuch numbers, nor in ſuch variety, as in the northern parts of the Atlantic ocean.

There are no deer in Oonalaſhka, or any other of theſe iſlands; not have they any domeſtic animals, not even dogs. Hence it is evident, that the ſea and rivers ſupply the inhabitants chiefly with food. They are obliged, alſo, to the ſea for wood; I mean drift-wood; for, not a ſtick grows on any of the iſlands, nor on the adjacent coaſts of the continent.

There are a great variety of plants at Oonalaſhka; and, moſt of them were in bloom, the latter end of June. Several of them are ſuch as we find in Europe; and, in many parts of America, particularly in Newfoundland.
Berries there are of various kinds; ſuch as bramble-berries, cranberries, hurtle-berries, heath-berries, &c. and, alſo, a brown berry, ſomewhat the taſte of a ſloe, from which brandy might be diſtilled. Of culinary plants, they have wild purſlane, pea-tops, a kind of ſcurvy-graſs, creſſes, and ſome others, all very palatable. On the low grounds, is plenty of graſs, which grows very thick and long, and in which ca • tle might ſubſiſt at Oonalaſhka, the whole year, without being houſed; and the ſoil, in many places, ſeems capable of producing grain, roots and vegetables, but none is cultivated.

The people of Oonalaſhka bury their dead on the ſummit of hills, and raiſe a little hillock over the grave. In a walk, ſays Captain Cooke, into the country, one of the natives, who attended me, pointed out ſeveral; and, one in particular, by the ſide of the road, over which was raiſed a heap of ſtones; and, I obſerved, that, every one who paſſed, added a ſtone to the number.

They are remarkably chearful and friendly among each other. The Ruſſians keep up a reſerve among them; and have no connexion with their women, merely becauſe they are not chriſtians. The venereal diſeaſe is general amongſt them; and they are ſubject to cancers, which thoſe who are afflicted with, take great pains to conceal. They do not appear to be long-lived; Captain Cooke ſaw none, ſeemingly, more advanced in life, than between 50 and 60.

The natives of Oonalaſhka, and thoſe on the northweſt ſide of America, reſemble the Greenlanders and Eſkimaux, not only in various particulars of perſon, dreſs, weapons, canoes, and the like, but in their language, which warrants this judgment, that there is great reaſon to believe theſe nations are of the ſame extraction. If ſo, there can be little doubt of a northern communication of ſome ſort, by ſea, between this ſide of America and the eaſt ſide, through Baffin's-bay, which communication, however, may be effectually ſhut up againſt ſhips by ice, and other impediments.

div.head: OF THE SCHAMANE RELIGION.
div.p: HAVING had occaſion to ſpeak of the pagan religion of the Siberians and Eaſtern Iſlanders, and having entered but ſlightly into the doctrines of Schamaniſm, my reader will probably not be diſpleaſed with ſome further account of it; I will therefore lay before him the great outlines of it, without deſcending to the minutiae.

The ſeveral pagan nations that inhabit the Ruſſian empire, are diſtinguiſhed as the profeſſors of three religions: the Schamane, that of Lama, and that of the Bramins. The laſt is the faith of only a ſmall number
of Indians found in this empire; the former is by far the moſt numerous, branching out into the different ſects of Finns, Tartars, Samojedes, Eaſtjaiks, Manſhours, Mongols, &c.

The Schamane idolatry is one of the moſt ancient that exiſts; it is the ſource or origin of the Lama, the Bramine, and various, other, pagan ſects. This idolatrous ſect is without much order or connexion, and is full of abſurdity; but I will endeavour to throw it into the beſt general ſyſtem I can, without entering into the various diverſities, as followed by different ſects.

Among all the Schamanes, women are held much inferior to men; and are thought to have been created merely for ſenſual pleaſure, to people the world, and look after domeſtic affairs; of courſe, are treated with great ſeverity and contempt. They are ſcarce allowed the common prerogatives of humanity; are held as impure, and reprobated by the gods; are conſidered as noxious during the period of their ſexual revolutions; and in child-birth are ſuppoſed dangerous and fatal both to men and animals. They are prohibited the worſhip of idols; and are thought to defile every thing they touch. They are conſidered as articles of merchandize; and a woman delivered of twins or a deformed child, is thought to have had commerce with the devil.

Yet, notwithſtanding this univerſal contempt of the female ſex, they admit the women to be prieſteſſes, and aſcribe to them equal pre-eminence and power with their prieſts, and reverence ſuch women as much. Both prieſts and prieſteſſes are diſtinguiſhed from the laity no otherwiſe than by their peculiar manner, and a little more knowledge of the ceremonies of their faith. Some are enthuſiaſts, ſome impoſtors, but the greateſt number are a compound of both.

Their dreſs has been already deſcribed, and a plate given to repreſent it. (See that of Tunguſe Sorcery.) The drum is the principal implement of their magic; and they pretend to beat it in ſuch a manner, as to make ſpirits appear and diſappear at pleaſure. This drum has been particularly deſcribed when we treated of Lapland. If it was cuſtomary for prieſts of antiquity to follow armies to war, it is poſſible that the uſe of the drum in regiments might have originated in this religious tabor.

The principles and notions of the Schamanes are imperfect, obſcure, confuſed, and contradictory; but they all agree in eſſentials. They all believe a univerſal God, the creator of all things; that he loves his creation; knows every thing, and is all-powerful; but pays no attention to the particular actions of man, being too great for them to offend him, and to do any thing meritorious in his ſight. Of courſe, as he neither puniſhes
nor rewards, it is uſeleſs to love him, and there is no reaſon to fear him.
Moſt of theſe heathens think that God is inviſible; that he has a human figure, and that he dwells in the ſun or the ſky; whilſt others take the ſun itſelf to be God.

Different nations have different divinities, with different influences; but they are all ſuppoſed ſubordinate to the controul of the Great Creator. Some of theſe deities are beneficent perſons, ſome maleficent. Of the latter, Schaïtan is the head of all the reſt; they conſider him as the moſt powerful being, after the ſupreme God; repreſent him as violently wicked, but think it poſſible to appeaſe him; and that the Schamans, or prieſts, are particularly in his favour. They hold evil to be a ſelf-exiſting ſubſtance, diſtinguiſhed by a variety of names; but all their notions, on this head, are confuſed, and unconnected. Theſe evil ſpirits are ſuppoſed to be lords of the earth, lords of iron, ſpirits of the mountains, demons of the foreſts, gods of inſects, and to dwell in the water, under the earth, in volcanoes and in foreſts.

Beſides theſe different deities, they addreſs a certain worſhip to the manes of their anceſtors, of the ſettlers of colonies, heroes, and all the prieſts and prieſteſſes of Schamaniſm; attributing to theſe demi-gods, a perfect
knowledge of every thing below, and a power to procure happineſs, or ſuccour, to their applicants and votaries.

The notions they have of the world, and the univerſe, are confined within the narrow bounds of that knowledge they are able to acquire in the deſarts. They conceive the world to be eternal; and, that future life, is but a continuation of the preſent.

Man, according to them, is compoſed of body and ſoul; is free, and his actions arbitrary; and, as the gods are indifferent to the actions of man, he is at liberty to act as he pleaſes. Health, a thriving flock, a numerous progeny, and a frequent enjoyment of ſenſual embraces, conſtitute their ſupreme felicity; misfortunes, and the want of theſe enjoyments, are their greateſt evils.

All the profeſſors of Schamaniſm, believe an exiſtence after death; but have ſuch uncomfortable ideas of that ſtate, as to dread it. They ſuppoſe death to be a change of the preſent life, into a ſubterraneous one, of the ſame kind; but purely intellectual and ſpiritual, though gloomy and melancholy. They attribute a ſoul to every animal; and, though they are convinced, that every thing rots by diſſolution, they bury, with the dead, implements for his uſe in the other world. The more eaſtern Siberians, the Kurilians, and Kamtſchadales, maintain, like the Mahomedans, that the future
life, though a continuation of the preſent, will be more perfect, and their enjoyments greater; that they ſhall poſſeſs more wealth and finer women; of courſe, they meet death with ardor, and often put an end to their exiſtence here, with the utmoſt coolneſs.

The ceremonies of their worſhip differ, according to the different nations; but all conſiſt in prayers, the worſhip of the beneficent divinities, ſacrificing offerings, magic rites, and ſuperſtitious mummery. The adorations, both public and private, prove, that many of theſe nations fear the gods, and ſeveral diſcover a ſincere devotion. All their prayers are very laconic. The laity, by ſhort, but devout invocations, pray for a ſupply of what they want. The ſupplicant turns his face to the ſun, to a mountain, a river, or an idol; and invokes them, as do the Roman Catholics, with great fervency, calling on every ſaint by his proper name.

Their magic ceremonies are deſigned to appeaſe malignant ſpirits; and are ſo abſurd, and contain ſo much viſible impoſture, that we cannot allow theſe people that indulgent pity we owe to men under the guidance of ignorant and deluded prieſts. The laity have honeſt and good deſigns, in their idol-worſhip; but, the prieſts, impoſe on their ſimplicity; and, we find, that fraud and fanaticiſm, are not incompatible in the human mind.

But, in ſpite of all that obſcurity and confuſion, which prevail in the religion of the Schamans, and its mythology, we cannot but diſcover, through them, the general notions of natural religion, as well as various ceremonies of Moſaic law. The ſacred fire, the oblations, the adorations, the opinions with reſpect to women, with many other articles of Schamane faith, ſeem to be borrowed from the ceremonial of Judaiſm. The chief cauſes that contribute to perpetuate their errors, are, the ſenſuality and materialiſm of all their opinions; their wild and vagabond way of life; their extreme poverty, and, of courſe, their total want of education. All theſe obſtacles, in conjunction, are a bar to their improvements; but if, in a future period, theſe, or the greateſt part of them, ſhould be removed; there is every reaſon to ſuppoſe, from their tractable and excellent diſpoſition, they may be induced to ſhake off their errors; and, that the chriſtian religion, will be tranſplanted into theſe, the remoteſt regions of the earth.

div.head: A DESCRIPTION OF LITTLE RUSSIA. From Perry, Hanway, King, Wraxall, Coxe, and others.
div.p: HAVING treated largely of the wide, extended and uncivilized parts of this vaſt empire, it is neceſſary I ſhould give my readers ſome account of that part which is called Little Ruſſia; and which includes the kingdoms of Moſcow and Aſtracan; parts into which, within theſe 50 years, European manners have been introduced: and, in doing this, I will reſume that ſyſtem I had adopted in the firſt volume of this work; but which the celebrated journal of Pallas induced me to drop, whilſt ſpeaking of Siberia and Tartary.

div.head: CHAP. I. Of the Country, Climate, and Productions.
div.p: THE country compriſed under the name of Ruſſia, or the Ruſſias, is of greater extent than all the reſt of Europe; or, than was the Roman empire, in the zenith of its power. It ſtretches from the Baltic, and Sweden, on the weſt, beyond Kamtſchatka, and the Oriental Iſles, 5,000 miles, and upwards, eaſtward, to the moſt weſtern ſhore of the American continent; which, as I have already obſerved, is divided from the eaſtern coaſt of Siberia, by a ſtreight of only 13 leagues in breadth. On the north, it is bounded by the Frozen Ocean; and extends, on the ſouth-eaſt, to China and Perſia. The greateſt part of this empire lies in Aſia; of this, we have already treated; I ſhall, therefore, confine myſelf now to that part which lies in Europe.

Little Ruſſia then extends from the 47th degree of north-latitude, to the 70th, or further north, but is ſcarce habitable nearer the pole; and, from the 21ſt degree of longitude to the 70th, reckoning from the meridian of London. In the ſouthern provinces, the longeſt day does not exceed fifteen hours and a half; whereas, in the moſt northern, the ſun does not ſet, in ſummer-time, for the ſpace of two months together; and here, during the winter, which generally continues
ſeven months, the whole country is covered with ſnow, a yard or two deep, and the rivers are all frozen up. It is natural to ſuppoſe, therefore, that where the climate is ſo various, there muſt be as great a diverſity of ſoil.

Dr. King, who reſided eleven years in Ruſſia, ſays, that the cold, at Peterſburgh, which is in the latitude of 60°, is, during the months of December, January, and February, uſually, by Fahrenheit's thermometer, from eight to 15, and 20 degrees below 0; that is, from 40 to 52 degrees below the freezing point; that the inhabitants have very little comfort in their winter-days, and ſpend moſt of their time by the fire-ſide; for, though the ſun may be a little above the horizon, for • wo or three hours, it is ſeldom ſeen, on account of the thick fogs, which ſo darken the air, that it may be rather called dawn, than day-light. The cold weather begins in Auguſt; and, every one is wrapped in furs till May following. The ice, in their rivers, is a yard thick. It is difficult, ſays Dr. King, for an inhabitant of a temperate clime, to have any idea of their cold. When a perſon walks out, in winter, the cold makes the eyes water; and, that water, freezes on the eye-laſhes, ſo as to hang in iſicles. Theſe iſicles may be ſeen hanging at the chin of their peaſants, who wear their beards, like a lump of ice; but, even in this ſtate, the icy beard defends the glands of the throat, which the ſoldiers, who wear no beards, are obliged to
guard, by tying a handkerchief under the chin. All the parts of the face are liable to be frozen, though the perſon ſo frozen is not himſelf ſenſible of it; but is commonly appriſed of it by thoſe who meet him, and adviſed to rub his face with ſnow, which is their mode of thawing it, for the part frozen always turns white; ſhould this be omitted, and the perſon ſo frozen pproach a fire, or dip his ears, noſe, or chin, in warm water, the frozen part will inſtantly mortify, and drop off. In ſevere winters, birds have been ſo benumbed, as to be unable to fly; and carters ſitting in their loaded carriages, have been found frozen to death. When the thermometer has been at 25 degrees below 0, boiling water thrown up into the air, and ſpread by an engine, has fallen to the ground in ice. But, notwithſtanding this ſeverity of the cold, the inhabitants have ſuch various means to guard againſt it, that they ſuffer much leſs from it, than might be expected. Mr. Coxe ſays, that, when he was there, in January, the mercury in Fahrenheit's thermometer, fell to 63 below the freezing point, and yet it did not detain him at home; he walked out, as uſual, with no other precaution than his peliſſe, fur-boots and cap; and, as the ſun ſhone bright, he found it by no means unpleaſant. The common people continued at their work, as uſual; and the drivers plied in the ſtreets, with their ſledges, ſeemingly unaffected with the froſt; their beards were incruſted with ice, and the horſes covered with iſicles. The people did not, during this extreme cold, add to
their ordinary cloathing. They are careful to preſerve their extremities, by covering their legs, hands, and head, with fur; but leave their necks quite bare, and their breaſts only covered with a coarſe ſhirt. During this time, continues Mr. Coxe, many women were employed in waſhing in the river, making holes in the ice with a hatchet, dipping their linen into the water with their bare hands, and beating it with flat ſticks. The ice formed again, almoſt as ſoon as they broke it; and, yet they would ſtand hours at this work—a proof that the human body may be brought to endure all extremes.

Coachmen and ſervants, waiting for their maſters, have been killed by the froſt: to guard, as much as poſſible, againſt this, great fires, of whole trees, piled up, are made, in the court yards of the palace, and moſt frequented parts of the town, to warm the air. The rain that falls in this country yearly, exceeds that which falls in England, in the proportion of 22 to 19.

Ruſſia is, in general, a flat country, except in the north. From Peterſburgh to Pekin in China, through Independant Tartary, ſcarce a mountain is to be ſeen; and, from Peterſburgh to the north of France, by Dantzic, Hamburgh, and Amſterdam, there is not the ſmalleſt hill.

The moſt conſiderable rivers are, 1ſt, the Wolga, which, after traverſing the greateſt part of Muſcovy, in a courſe of 3000 miles, empties itſelf into the Caſpian ſea. It is, in moſt places, ſo ſhallow, that veſſels, drawing above five feet water, can ſcarcely float, except in flood-times, when the largeſt flat-bottomed veſſels, even carrying 600 tuns, find ſufficient water. The ſtream, in common, does not run more than one mile an hour; but, in flood-time, it will run three miles. The water-men, who navigate this river, do it by warping. They have three boats to carry out theſe warps, which they take in forwards, and thus get on againſt the ſtream, when the wind is not with them, 30 miles a-day. Their barges are ſo large as to carry from 150 to 200 men. In all its long courſe, it has not a cataract to interrupt the navigation; and, by it, the city of Moſcow has a communication not only with all the ſouthern parts of Ruſſia, but even into Perſia, Georgia, Tartary, and all the countries bordering on the Caſpian ſea.

The Don is another great river; divides the eaſtern part of Ruſſia from Aſia; and, in its courſe eaſtwards, approaches ſo near the Wolga, that it was intended to cut a canal between the two; and it would have been done, but for the interruption of the Tartars. This river runs near 400 miles, and empties itſelf into the ſea of Aſoph. The Dnieper, which is likewiſe one of the largeſt rivers in Europe, has thirteen cataracts
within a ſmall diſtance; riſes •• ar the ſource of the Wolga, in the foreſt of the Volkenſki (a foreſt of 150 mile in length, and that reaches almoſt to the gates of Moſcow), about 100 miles from Smolenſko; ſeparates the Ukraine from Poland, and diſcharges itſelf into the Black Sea. By the acquiſition of the province of Mohilef, it is included within the Ruſſian territories. The northern, and north-eaſtern provinces, are, in a manner, deſart; but, the reſt of the country abounds with foreſts.
The principal cities are, Peterſburgh, Moſcow, Novogorod, Twer, Smolenſko, Kiova, Riga, Archangel, Caſan, and Aſtrachan. Of ſome of theſe I have already ſpoken.

Ruſſia being, for the moſt part, a level country, and extremely well watered by lakes and rivers, is abundantly fruitful. The communication of one part of the empire with another, is laid open, by roads and navigable canals; ſo that, the northern parts, which wanted corn and fruits, ſo plentiful in the ſouth, are now ſupplied with both. In the ſpring of the year, as ſoon as the ſnow is gone, which generally lies on the ground three months, the warm weather ſucceeds, every thing looks green, and the tulips, lilies of the valley, and many other fine flowers and herbs, ſpring up ſpontaneouſly, without culture; and vegetation is very quick, in all its branches. The ſhortneſs of the ſummer does not
allow the grain time to ripen well; but the peaſants contrive to dry it, in the following way: they conſtruct a wooden building, ſomething like the ſhell of a cottage, without windows; under this building is a large hollow, on which a fire being made, the new cut corn, in ear, is laid on the floor, till dry; after this, it is hung on frames, in the open air, and then threſhed. Paſtures and meadows are very prolific; but they have no fruits, except ſtrawberries and raſberries: as to the finer fruits, ſuch as pines, apricots, grapes, pears, and cherries, they cannot be obtained, but in hot-houſes. They have, however, excellent melons, pomegranates, and pines, from Aſtrachan. Grapes are brought, from Aſtrachan, to the Empreſs, every three days; a diſtance not leſs than 1500 miles. They are preſerved in ſand, and carried between two horſes, ſupported in the manner of a litter, and are 21 days on their journey.

The Ruſſes have a ſaying, That they are very rich in fiſh and bread; and, it may be added, they have good ſtore of horſes, cattle, and wild game. Proviſions are ſo cheap, that good beef may be bought for three farthings a pound; mutton and pork in proportion; and bread, at about one ſixth part of the uſual price in England. The broad-tailed ſheep are brought from Aſtrachan; and are, in flavour, ſomething like veniſon.

On account of the ſevere cold in this country, not only water-fowl, cranes, ſwans, ducks, geeſe, ſnipes, &c.
but almoſt all ſorts of land-birds, fly to the ſouthward, in winter, in infinite numbers; and back again in the ſpring, when the ſnow diſappears; which, in the latitude of Moſcow, is not till about the end of April.

Their horſes are not of a large breed; but, like thoſe of Scotland, hardy and ſerviceable; and are ſeldom ſhod, either in ſummer or winter. They have greyhounds, but no hounds. Their wild beaſts are, bears, foxes, boars, elks, deer, wolves, wild horſes, and wild ſheep. Captain Perry ſays, he ate part of a wild ſheep, which was purſued into a river by a wolf, and he thought it more tender and palatable than tame mutton. They have, alſo, martens, ſables, ermines, and two kinds of hares, one of which turns white in the winter, and changes again in ſummer.

There is no country, in Europe, better ſtocked with bees; and their woods, accordingly, afford great plenty of honey; and the wealthy burn nothing but wax-candles. The woods, and gardens, about Moſcow, are full of ſinging-birds; but there being few in the neighbourhood of Peterſburgh, government purchaſed as many as came to ſix or ſeven hundred pounds, and let them fly into the woods about that capital, where, it is ſaid, they have multiplied exceedingly.
With reſpect to the mines of this country, they have been treated of fully, when deſcribing Tartary and Siberia.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the People, and chief Cities.
div.p: NOTHING can be more erroneous, than the different accounts of the population of this empire. Voltaire tells us, that, by a liſt, taken in 1747, of all the males that paid the poll-tax, including boys and old men, the number amounted to near ſeven millions; and, if we reckon three times this number, for females, and perſons not regiſtered, it will make about 20 millions; and, to theſe add, 350,000 ſoldiers, and 200,000 nobility and clergy, and foreigners, exempted from the poll-tax, and the number will be about 20 millions and a half; which, with the conquered Tartars, may be eſtimated at 24 millions. But Mr. Coxe, in a much better calculation, in 1764, thinks, they may ſurely be ſtated at near 23 millions.

The Ruſſians are, generally ſpeaking, a perſonable people, rather Dutch-built, and inclined to be corpulent; at leaſt, this is what they admire: they are hardy, vigorous, and patient of labour. Their complexions differ from thoſe of the Engliſh, or Scots; but the women think an addition of red paint, heightens their beauty. Their eye-ſight ſeems to be defective; perhaps owing to the ſnow. The army poſſeſs a great ſhare of paſſive and active valour; will live hard, and ſubmit to the ſtricteſt diſcipline. The temper of the
Ruſſians, however, has not been much admired: they are held to have good parts, but to be very deceitful, and not to have a proper ſenſe of ſhame. Captain Perry, who was ſome time in that country, in the beginning of the preſent century, ſays, that the foreigners there uſed to ſay, That if you wiſh to know whether a Ruſs is an honeſt man, look in the palm of his hand, and, if you don't find hair grow there, never truſt him. When they flatter and ſooth, and profeſs, with oaths and aſſeverations, a great reſpect for you, be well upon your guard, for they mean to betray you; and ſo far are they wanting, continues he, in a ſenſe of ſhame, that they hold it a commendable quality, to be a ſharper; and ſay, that ſuch a man, underſtands the world, and will thrive: but, of an honeſt man, they ſay, Un cloup nemeit ſhiet; he is a blockhead, and knows not how to live. And, ſo little regard have they for their word, and ſo void of any notion of real honour, that they have not a word, in their language, to expreſs it. The czar, Peter, took a great deal of pains to inculcate proper principles into them; and they do not now, deſerve ſo ſevere a character. Mr. Coxe, who was there very lately, ſays, even the peaſants, in their common intercourſe, are remarkably polite to each other. They take off their caps at meeting, bow ceremoniouſly, and frequently and uſually exchange a ſalute. They accompany their ordinary diſcourſe with much action, and innumerable geſtures; and are exceedingly ſervile in their expreſſions of deference to their ſuperiors. In
accoſting a perſon of conſequence, they proſtrate themſelves, and even touch the ground with their heads— a kind of eaſtern homage. They are greedy, however, of money; and almoſt always demand previous payment, for any article they ſell; and they ſeem, in general, ſays Mr. Coxe, much inclined to thieving. It was found neceſſary to place a guard by the carriage, at night, where we ſtopped, or every article in it would have diſappeared before morning.

Among the better claſs of people, continues Mr. Coxe, nothing can exceed their hoſpitality. We could never pay a morning-viſit to any nobleman, without being detained to dinner. The principal perſons of diſtinction, keep open tables, and are highly obliged to perſons who reſort to them, without ceremony. Their tables are ſerved with great profuſion and taſte. They will, at the ſame time, have ſterlet (a kind of ſturgeon from the Wolga), veal from Archangel, mutton from Aſtrachan, beef from the Ukraine, and pheaſants from Hungary and Bohemia; and their common wines are, claret, burgundy, champaigne; and Engliſh beer, and porter, in perfection. Though they have adopted the delicacies of French cookery, they deſpiſe not the ſolid joints of the Engliſh. Before dinner, even in the houſes of perſons of the firſt diſtinction, a ſmall table is ſpread, in a corner of the drawing-room, covered with plates of caviare, dried and pickled herrings, ſmoked ham, or tongue, bread, butter and cheeſe; with bottles of different
liqueurs; a little of which is generally taſted before dinner. Their uſual hour of dining is three; their entertainments are regulated according to the French ceremonial; the wine being circulated, during meals; and, the diſhes are no ſooner removed, than the company retire into another room, and are ſerved with coffee, gentlemen as well as ladies.

Drunkenneſs is ſo common among the lower claſs of people, that it is ſcarcely eſteemed a vice. Captain Perry ſays, that, if we ride through Moſcow on a holiday, we ſhall ſee both prieſts and people drunk upon the ground; and, if you go to help one up, he will ſay, by way of excuſe, It is holiday-time. Nay, he ſays further, that their women of quality are ſo little aſhamed of drinking to exceſs, that they will acknowledge their having been drunk, and return thanks to their friends who made them ſo. This was, however, near a century ago; Mr. Coxe ſays now, that, among perſons of rank, they never deviate from the ſtricteſt ſobriety.

Mr. Wraxall tells us (and he travelled there in 1774), That the females in this country are all forced, and brought forward in deſpite of nature; that, during the winter-months, they are conſtantly in apartments heated by ſtoves to a great degree, from which they enter, upon a haſty, but hot ſummer, of two or three months. The conſequence of this, added to their
warm baths, of which they are very fond, is, that they want, like every other artificial production, the genuine flavor, which nature only can give; that charming firmneſs, and elaſticity of fleſh, ſo indiſpenſibly requiſite to conſtitute beauty. The ladies eſteemed as beauties here, are ponderous and maſſy; and lovelineſs ſeems to conſiſt in a woman's weighing near 200 lb. In giving a deſcription of ſome of the principal cities, I ſhall have occaſion to ſpeak of the people again, of courſe will drop the ſubject for the preſent.

Peterſburgh, the capital of the empire, was founded by Peter the Great, in the beginning of this century, and has amazingly increaſed in ſize within theſe fifty years. At the death of Peter, it did not contain above 80,000 inhabitants, and now the Ruſſians aſſert that there are 500,000; but this, ſays Mr. Marſhall, is an exaggeration. The number, ſays Mr. Coxe, is about 130,000; and the city is, perhaps, the only one in Europe where there are more births than deaths.

Peterſburgh lies in 60 degrees N. latitude, and is built at the mouth of the river Neva, on ſeveral iſlands, which were once nothing more than marſhy ſpots of mud, over-run with reeds, as indeed is all the country round; but the immortal founder, whoſe undertakings in every thing carried a magnificence of idea in them, converted a miſerable bog into a fine city; for Peterſburgh is the ſoul of commerce in all
theſe northern parts; it is the foundation on which all the Ruſſian naval force has been erected; is ſo well fortified, as to be impregnable; and the port on which their nurſery of ſailors moſt depends. But, notwithſtanding theſe capital circumſtances, it muſt be acknowledged very deficient, as a receptacle of the men of war of a great empire; for the depth of water; the freſhneſs of it; the docks, yards, every thing at Peterſburgh are againſt the uſe of it for that purpoſe. Indeed it is, at preſent, but an extenſive outline, which will require future ages to complete. It ſtands on a prodigious extent of ground; but, as the houſes in many places do not join, and great ſpaces are uncovered, it's real ſize cannot be aſcertained. The houſes, like thoſe of Amſterdam, are all built upon piles; and, indeed, the place very much reſembles the cities in Holland; the ſtreets being very broad, as broad as the high-ſtreet in Oxford; with canals running through many of them, and ſeveral planted, on each ſide the canal, with trees. Though there are ſome errors in the plan, there are alſo ſome regular and well-built ſtreets, chiefly paved; but many of them floored with timber, which, in accidents of fire, carry the communication rapidly. The houſes are very large, and the palaces of the nobility exceed, in ſize, thoſe of any other city. The public buildings are ſo numerous, as to conſtitute a fifth or ſixth part of the whole capital: and the houſes of the nobility are moſtly vaſt piles of building, and furniſhed in the ſame elegant ſtyle as at Paris or
